Now Term's return'd, again the crazy sound</br>Of bell half-crack'd, proclaims the hour of pray'rs;</br>Assembling duns the sported oak surround,</br>And useless plate lies rotting on the stairs.
Now loungers dull their matin rounds begin,</br>Now cheeks of half-starv'd scouts begin to bloom;</br>The rattling plates, and clashing glasses din,</br>Speak the full hall, and crouded common room.
Now down the far-fam'd High-street's crouded walk,</br>Stalks in slow pace the solitary Ralph;</br>With useful scorn regards the sneering talk,</br>The pointed finger, or the rude loud laugh.
Now many a freshman grim, of form uncouth,</br>The cub, half-grown, of some rude rustic bear,</br>Trips by his father's side, a hopeful youth,</br>Array'd in Sunday cloaths, and lank long hair.

Low his long coat in doubling volumes reaches,</br>With swelling sleeve, that dangles to and fro;</br>That with broad friendly flap to guard the breeches,</br>And this to give its wearer room to grow.

Behold him trembling 'fore the black-stol'd throng,</br>Which frighted freshmen with such terror view,</br>While fond papa proclaims in whispers loud,</br>"My Jack has read Cordery through and through."

Yet soon the youth forgets his rustic bent,</br>Laughs at the stiff-wigg'd strutting of the doctors,</br>Ticks with the tradesmen, thwacks the Ralphs in Lent,</br>His tutors mimic, and defies the proctors.
Audacious he, soon thinks it no disgrace,</br>When Kit from closet rears his hateful head,</br>And with quick hand, and grinning Gorgon face,</br>Lugs from a pocket sly citations dread.
See where the traces of a midnight rou,</br>In recent marks on staircase foul remain;</br>Where broken chairs in ruin sad lie low,</br>And many a fallen stone, and fractur'd pane.
Some stranger passing by, with wily air</br>And cautious hand a shatter'd fragment takes;</br>Then bids his son of riots rude beware,</br>"These Oxford scholars, boy, are horrid rakes."
Shall I remember, in far time to come,</br>When age has spread his wrinkles o'er my brow,</br>Quick travelling to the all-devouring tomb,</br>The happy, happy hours I spend here now,
Or think how fast the golden moments flow,</br>As Cynthia's rays upon the silver stream,</br>Fair as the flowret's diamond crest of dew,</br>Fair as the visions of a morning dream.
Hail!  lion proctor, hail too, jackall pro',</br>With gracious bow my homage due receive,</br>Hail, mighty pam of academic loo,</br>Hail, negro majesty of velvet sleeve.
How oft, like mouse from fierce Grimalkin's paw,</br>With trembling feet of fear from thee I've fled,</br>When passing, in thy Sultan frown I saw</br>Jobations, crosses, impositions, dread.
Will memory find, where I so oft was wont,</br>On Isis' stream to ply the frequent oar,</br>Sad Rosamunda's lonely tomb to haunt,</br>And dream I saw her tread the pebbled shore?
How oft awaken'd by ambition's calls,</br>Smit with the fond, the dear desire of fame,</br>I've scribbled verses on the boghouse walls,</br>And carv'd on wainscots, chairs, and stools, my name.
Haply some curious wight, in future time,</br>My worn initials on the wall may see,</br>And ah!  where then my hopes of fame for rhyme,</br>May ask, unthinkingly, "Pray, who was he?"

Bless'd be the man who then shall kindly say,</br>"I've heard him mention'd once, 'a strange young dog';</br>Who'd waste, in scribbling rhymes, the live-long day,</br>You've seen his verses, doubtless, in the bog."
Oft would his wiser friends tell him to chuse,</br>(For wiser friends sure know what lore is best)</br>Studies of profit for the threadbare muse,</br>Was by the sons of want alone profest.
Thus job'd, his wiser friends but job'd in vain,</br>The youth disdain'd, and their advice was nought;</br>He still pursu'd the dull poetic strain,</br>And neither logic read, nor logic wrote.
In vain did Prudence point to system plann'd,</br>Did Poverty with famish'd eye-ball stare,</br>Ambition wave his shadow-grasping hand,</br>And small-ey'd Avarice knit his brow of care.
His strains, perhaps — for verses publish'd he,</br>(Odd things does fate sometimes together join)</br>With many a sprig of straying flower you'll see,</br>Portmanteau's sage and learned boxes line.
Yet think not ill of Clubbs's neglected rhymes,</br>Though of fame's far-resounding voice they miss,</br>Precepts too good they held for such bad times,</br>Too moral verses for an age like this.
At him nor let the critic's growl be hurl'd,</br>But with the action learn to view its ends;</br>Like others, though he wrote to mend the world,</br>He publish'd only to oblige his friends.</br>
